children.text:
In Fortran, we can use read(*,*) to read from standard input. Let's see. So the code outline would be:

program main

    integer :: N, i, A

children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
idorder(:)

        idorder(A) = i
    end do

    end do
    write(*,*)  ! to add a new line after

end program main

children.text: Wait, the colon in the format specifier means that if there are no more items, the edit descriptor is skipped. So for example, using (I0,X) for each element would produce a trailing space, but with (I0,:,X) the X is only output if there is another item. So for N elements, the X would be printed after each except the last. So this format would produce the numbers separated by spaces, without a trailing space. Then, the code can be written as:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: N, i, A
    integer, allocatable :: idorder(:)

    read(*,*) N
    allocate(idorder(N)) do i = 1, N
        read(*,*) A
        idorder(A) = i
    end do

    print '(*(I0,:,X))', (idorder(i), i=1,N)

end program main

This way, the print statement outputs all the elements separated by spaces, with no trailing space, and adds a new line automatically.
